page.title: 08NATURAL RECLAMATION
page.content:
There are 17,000 acres of China Clay extraction around St.Austell; the centre of this occurs in our study area. consequentky rhe landscape is dominated by deep pits and huge conical or barrow-like tips of waste.
Some of the China Clay residues are pumped into the pits as slurry. The pits usually fill with water and are then called lagoons. The sides quickly become colonised by alder, willow and other wetland plants.
The oldest tips have been recolonised by natural vegetation from the surrounding, undamaged heath. Colonisers include ling, heathers, gorse, rhododendron, bilberry, broom, brambles, foxgloves, sorrels and grasses. Natural recolonisation takes many decades to reach completion.
